title: Wheaton College offering scholarship to student from country affected by Trump travel ban
text:
One Massachusetts college is responding to President Trump’s travel ban by offering a full four-year scholarship to a student from one of the seven affected countries.

Wheaton College, a small liberal arts school in Norton, specified that preference would be given to a student from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen. As of Monday, 10 students have applied for the scholarship, college officials said.

“Wheaton is a global institution that is dedicated to improving the world by advancing knowledge and sharing it,” Wheaton College President Dennis M. Hanno said in a statement. “The current executive order on immigration endangers our ability to deliver on that mission.”

Currently, two out of the 1,650 students at the Norton school hail from one of the seven countries, said spokesman Michael Graca.

The scholarship would cover four years, including room and board, which currently costs $61,500 a year, Graca said.

While the traditional admission deadline has passed, Wheaton College has re-opened admissions and is now accepting applications through March 1.

If a student receives the scholarship and is unable to acquire a visa and get into the United States by next fall, the college will defer admission, said Grant M. Gosselin, vice president and dean of admission and student aid.

“These students have faced hardships unlike anything we could imagine and will need significant assistance to make acquiring an education possible,” Gosselin said. “We believe it is our responsibility as contributors to global education to make this commitment.”
